paper_abstract: The following multiple integral is involved in the neutron star theory: tau(epsilon, nu) = 1/omega(epsilon) integral(pi/2)(0) d theta sin(theta) integral(infinity)(0) dn n(2) integral(infinity)(0) dp h(n, p theta, epsilon, nu) where h(n, p, theta, epsilon, nu) = psi(z)phi(n - epsilon - z) + psi(-z)phi(n - epsilon + z) - psi(z)phi(n + epsilon - z) - psi(z)phi(n + epsilon + z) and z = root p(2) + (nu sin(theta))(2), psi(x) = 1/exp x + 1, phi(x) = x/exp x + 1. omega(epsilon) is a normalization function. The aim is to get a table for tau(epsilon, nu) for some values of (epsilon, nu) in [10(-4), 10(4)] x [ 10(-4), 10(3)] and then to interpolate for the others. We present a new strategy, using the Gauss-Legendre quadrature formula, which allows to have one code available whatever the values of nu and epsilon are. We guarantee the accuracy of the final result including both the truncation error and the round-off error using Discrete Stochastic Arithmetic. (c) 2005 IMACS. Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
paper_title: Reliable computation of a multiple integral involved in the neutron star theory
